items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from 7:00pm tonight, Sunday 5th October, and for at least the next 24 hours. This is due to tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth and creating a natural tide locking effect. This will restrict the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are currently monitoring the situation and will update this message if necessary. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. We will update this message by 3pm tomorrow, Monday 6th October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from 8pm tonight, Sunday 5th October, and for at least the next 24 hours. This is due to tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth and creating a natural tide locking effect. This will restrict the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. We are currently monitoring the situation and will update this message if necessary. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. We will update this message by 3pm tomorrow, Monday 6th October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from 7:15pm tonight, Sunday 5th October, and for at least the next 24 hours. This is due to tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth and creating a natural tide locking effect. This will restrict the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. We are currently monitoring the situation and will update this message if necessary.  Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. We will update this message by 3pm tomorrow, Monday 6th October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk coast at Southwold
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 8pm and 10pm tonight, Sunday 5th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to Storm Amy. We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.69mAODN at 9pm, on Sunday 5th October, which is 0.75m above tide tables, wind Force 6, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Monday 6th October, or if the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. We will continue to monitor levels closely. It is possible that we will issue further flood alerts over the next few days.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. We will continue to monitor levels closely. It is possible that we will issue further flood alerts over the next few days.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 12:00 on 05/10/25, may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 11cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next 5 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 05/10/25, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further rainfall is forecast over the next couple of days. We continue to monitor the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: Upper River Aire catchment
items.message: The flood alert has been removed; the levels have fallen an there is no further significant rainfall expected.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: Strong winds and large waves this afternoon may lead to flooding from overtopping and sea spray. Flooding of roads, low lying land and exposed areas of the coast is possible. Property flooding is not expected. Flooding is possible between 3:45PM and 6:00PM on Sunday 05/10/2025. We are entering a period of high tides through the week commencing 06/10/2025, and this flood alert may be reissued in advance of future high tides. We are closely monitoring the situation. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9PM on 05/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Ure

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ure, Swinney Beck, Bishop Monkton Beck, River Skell, River Laver, River Tutt, Stainley Beck

items.message: River levels in this area have now fallen below levels of concern.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 10:30pm and 12:30am tonight, Sunday 5th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to Storm Amy. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 3.01mAODN at 11:30pm, on Sunday 5th October, which is 0.55m above tide tables, wind Force 5, Westerley. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Monday 6th October, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message:
Large waves and sea spray are expected to affect the seafront as a result of Storm Amy between 5pm and 7pm, Sunday 05 October 2025. 

Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront.  Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. 

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 3.88mAODN at 18:00, on Sunday 05 October 2025, which is 0.59m above tide tables, wind Force 5, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). 

The following tide on Monday 06 October 2025 at 06:45am is not currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. 

Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. 

We will update this message by 8pm Sunday, 05 October 2025.

items.description: Upper River Ouse

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message:
Levels on the River Ouse have now peaked. However, flooding is possible through Sunday 05/10/2025 as levels remain high. 
Flooding is forecast to affect riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. No further significant rainfall is expected today, and we expect levels to fall slowly during the day.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. 
 
This message will be updated by 9PM on Sunday 05/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
Coast from Ramsgate to Kingsdown
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: The previous Flood Alert in force for this morning’s tide has now been removed.  Further high tides are predicted for Wednesday 8 October and Thursday 9 October, and there is a possibility further Flood Alerts could be issued in relation to these tides during the coming week.

items.description: River Severn in Shropshire
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains possible for today, 05/10/25. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. 

Predicted Peak :- Crew Green 4.95m to 5.1m today 05/10/2025 at 17:00. No other gauge locations are expected to reach flood alert levels. 

No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until 06/10/25. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 

This message will be updated by 10am 06/10/2025, or as the situation changes

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 11pm tonight, and 1am Monday 6th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to Storm Amy. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.40mAODN at midnight, on Sunday 5th October, which is 0.49m above tide tables, wind Force 4, Westerley. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Monday 6th October, or if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Crouch, River Roach, North Sea

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 10:30pm and 12:30am tonight, Sunday 5th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to Storm Amy. Tide levels will be high at Battlesbrigde, and Hullbridge riversides. Creeksea Ferry Road onto Wallasea Island may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 3.01mAODN at 11:30pm, on Sunday 5th October, which is 0.55m above tide tables, wind Force 5, Westerley. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Monday 6th October, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message: Tidal conditions have improved and no flooding is expected. However, high spring tides are rising towards their peak early next week and we will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

items.description: Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River and lake levels remain high.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the morning but no further flooding is expected.
We continue to closely monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 06/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River and lake levels remain high following recent heavy rain.
Areas most at risk include The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the morning but no further flooding is expected.
We continue to closely monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 06/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk coast from Lowestoft to Bawdsey
items.message: The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. We will continue to monitor levels closely. It is possible that we will issue further flood alerts over the next few days.

items.description: Upper River Ribble, Hodder
items.message:
There is potential for some heavy showers in the next few hours, but the main band of rain has passed through and river levels are reaching their peak, if not already falling, and are below Flood Alert level.   

The flood alert has been removed but river levels may remain high for some time. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

items.description: The Norfolk coast from Caister to Gorleston, including Great Yarmouth
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Keswick Campsite
items.message:
River and lake levels remain high following Storm Amy. 
Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site .
There may be some isolated showres throughout today, Sunday 05/10/25 which will keep river and lake levels high.
We are continuing to closely monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 06/10/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Isolated low lying properties along the tidal River Waveney
items.message: River levels are now steadily falling, but still remain quite high in some locations. A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Riverside properties along the tidal River Yare including Cantley, Brundall and Reedham
items.message: River levels are now steadily falling, but still remain quite high in some locations. A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The A12 at Blythburgh
items.message: Levels are now below the flood warning risk thresholds. There remains an Alert in place for low lying land and footpaths. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.
